oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Sesquicentennial International Exposition, Philadelphia
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Large lithographic poster advertising the 1926 Sesquicentennial International Exposition in Philadelphia. Illustration is of a "flapper-like" woman entwined in an American flag in front of Independence Hall.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides; Lithographs; Exhibitions
Broadsides; Lithography - 20th Century; Smith, Dan, 1865-1934; Sesqui-Centennial International Exposition (1926 : Philadelphia, Pa.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dan Smith
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The 1876 Philadelphia World's Fair was a successful celebration of the 150th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence. The 1926 fair was less successful but pioneered talking movies, colored lights, and a P. A. system.
